column17: Was the participant aware of the goal?1= YES  0 = NO
column18: Transcribe the written answer of each participant's guess  of the study's goal.
ACTIONS WITH UNUSAL BODY PARTS
FACIAL EMOTIONS AND FRUSTRATION
DIFFERENT ACTIONS CAN AFFCT HOW YOU PERCIEVE THINGS
MOOD AFFECTS SKILLS
STRESS LEVELS AND HUMOUR
COGNITIVE FUNCTION
PSYCHOMETRIC COORDINATION
HOLD PEN WITHOUT SALVIA DRIPPING
SELF CONTROL
PERSONALITY AND PSYCHOMOTOR COORDINATION
HOLDING PEN IN UNCOMFORTBALE POSITION AFFECTS HUMOUR
PERFORMANCE USING OTHER BODY PARTS
HOW EASY TO WRITE WITH MOUTH
COORDINATION AND DISABILITY
CAUSING A SMILE WOTH PEN LEADS TO HIGHER AMUSEMENT FOR CARTOONS
PEOPLE WHO USE MOUTH TO WRITE FIND IT HARD
CARTOONS AFFECT ABILITY TO PERFORM TASK
USING DIFFERENT BODY PARTS
ABILITY TO PERFORM TASKS WITH MOUTH - DISABILITIES
HOW PEOPLE REACT TO SITUATIONS
NO CLUE
TASKS USING UNFAMILIAR MUSCLE GROUPS
NO IDEA, SORRY
MOUTH CONTROL
FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS AND NOT TO CHEAT
DIFFERENT STYLES OF WRITING
BRAIN FUNCTIONS WITH PEN IN MOUTH
FACED WITH CHALLENGE THEY AREN'T GOOD AT
STEADINESS
DISABILITY AND LEARNING TO DRAW
To explore ability to concentrate on a task while using your natural abilities in a different way.
To see if we are distracted by the cartoons so are better able to write with our mouths.
Frustration at trying to hold the pen may limit amusement! But then there would be a pen-less control... Concentration may affect amusement?
To see what the effect the pen has on my ability to perform certain tasks. If the pen makes tasks harder because I wasn't able to use my hands.
To see how concentrating on holding a pen in your mouth affects emotions/understanding.
To see if mood affects people's ability to control the pen.
To see how well people can coordinate whilst being recorded.
Seeing if sense of humour/personality correlated with motor function – maybe people who would find the cartoons funny would be more/less able to control the pen with their mouth.
To establish how someone can multi-task with challenging tasks and simple instructions. Also, to establish ease of simple tasks when distracted.

To see how disabled people have to communicate. Also, trying out different low-tech methods of communication that less able people may have to use. Seeing how our co-ordination varies depending on which part of the body we are forced to use.
To see how hard it is to perform simple tasks in a way that you don't normally do. Allowing for development in the area of producing products/technology to help disabled people.

Identifying how subjects identify workarounds when required to do a task in a way that they are physically disadvantaged and illustrating the difficulties faced by people who have to do this every day.

To see if the response to cartoons (i.e. humorous media) is altered in any way by the facial muscles' position - when holding the pen in the correct way, the facial muscles seemed to be in a similar position to that of a smile. Maybe something to  do with the association between a smile and humour?
Emotions and bodily movements.
How easy it is to hold a pen in your mouth (how well you can follow instructions? Haha)
To investigate how using part of the body to carry out a task that you ouldn't normally use affects mood/amusement. i.e. if found too difficult, you may be less amused.

We are so used to thinking about a task and writing with our hands that the way we think is not something we ever consider. So perhaps the experiment is to explore how different one's thought processes are when using a pen in one's mouth, instead of one's hand.
Concentrating on holding pen, so don't really pay attention to cartoons - how much concentration was given to both tasks?

The purpose was to understand if there are effective ways to perform basic essential functins, such as writing without using our hands. It may have also been an experiment to understandw whether using different/non-traditional parts of our body inhibits our ability to concentrate & understand written material (such as cartoons). Does it confuse our brain?

Find out if it's easier for people to learn how to use other parts of their body (their mouth) for purposes they wouldn’t normally use it for (writing). This can be easier & cheaper than investiging in expensive technologies that are hard to learn properly.
The effect of current mood on the ability to carry out challenging tasks.
To understand people's emotions, but when put out of their comfort zone.
To see if understanding affects psychomotoric capabilities
To see if communicating with different parts of the body, which are not normally used works - aiming to find an alternative for people who are unable to communicate/write conveniently.
The effect on senses whilst uncomfortable
To test cognitive and moto function in order to understand how those who cannot use their hands write. Additionally can be used as a measure of how well people can adapt to difficult situations.

I think the purpose may have been to observe the various ways in which individuals may try in order to make the task simpler and how this correlates with their personality and social situations e.g. job and age.

To test the ability of people to utilise tools designed for one appendage (e.g. a pen for the hands) using an unorthodox appendage (such as pen/mouth) for testing ways for people with disabilities to compensate for their condition.
Whether a semi-smile facial expression (induced by holding a pen with teeth) would lead to higher rating of the cartoons.
To see whether the brain is capable of learning how to carry out simple tasks using body parts that are not usually used when carrying out specific tasks.
To see if I can perform tasks using other kinds of movements/with diff (unusual) part of the body.
To identify how difficult it is to co-ordinate having a pen in your mouth whilst also completing a task booklet (psychomotor coordintion)
To see how good motor skills are.
To see how well people can adapt to only beig able to use their mouth to write.
To see if our amusement affected our ability to to control our smiling /lip gestures
To examine the behaviour of participants as they use the pen
To examine whether humour was easier or more difficult to elicit after exposure to frustrating stimuli
Pretty sure it has more to do with how we react to the cartoons but I can't really imagine what exactly
The purpose of the experiment was to find out the dexterity of different people while they perform tasks they usually wouldn't do
To assess whether people doing something they find difficult are less likely to be amused
How you react when put in an unfamiliar situation maybe?
To register facial expressions while carrying out tasks eg if smiling or embarrassed

I think the purpose of this experiment is to see how changing emotions effect how well we can draw with the pen. IE- when we are connecting the dots we're concentrating therefore we may produce better lines. However when we are looking at the cartoons we may be slightly amused and not realy concentrating on how well our drawn lines are.
Research for new technologies for physically impaired people or to show how difficulties arise from being physically impaired.
To find a link between an ability to adapt to new motor activities and psychological traits, perhaps?
To see if a person improves under different circumstances?
To see if I used my mouth the whole time or I cheated
To measure cognitive ability while performing a complex/unfamiliar physical task
No idea!
Really not sure!
To see if I have a sense of humour
To see how you would cope if you couldn't use your hands
To see if by using a different part of your body influences the way you use the pen effectively
To acertain dexterity when holding pen in mouth
To check the participant's patience and pleasure in undertaking the task
To see how I manage using a part of my body not normally used for a certain action
To see if I got annoyed by the tasks and find the cartoons less amusing
To establish the dificulty impaired people have in their daily tasks.
I believe it's to see how long some people take. Perhaps perfectionists would take longer whereas lazy people would take less time.
I think the purpose of this experiment is to see how people react doing different things and the way they deal with things
To find out whether I could use the pen in my mouth to a degree of accuracy
To see how people perform tasks when asked to write in a different way
To test how easy it is to adapt to a new way of doing a usual task and whether you can still concentrate and think about other activities at the same time
I think it may be *illegible* of the facial expression. And the comics that affect your feelings or emotions eg. smiling
to see if I would still use the pen as told even on my own
to see if I could draw with my mouth which I normally don’t use to draw
to see whether different moods (third task) had any bearing on performing a task Im not used to
to test whether being physically impaired affects ones enjoyment of humorous/entertaining stimulus
to understand the effectiveness of writing using your mouth and the affect that this has on peoples wellbeing
to discern the efficacy of this particular technique as an alternate form of communication for disabled people e.g. someone experiencing paralysis as a result of spinal injury
to see how well people who are unable to use their hands to write can function at answering and understand tasks when using another means of writing
interpret and experience what it feels like for disabled people who don’t have limbs to write for a person who does have the ability to write
film someone being silly with a pen in their mouth

to see how well people perform doing certain tasks with different parts of their body they wouldn’t normally use for those tasks and find out how the ability to use these unusual parts of the body for the task will develop
the purpose of the experiment is to test the patience and adaptability of the person taking it to see how they ract using certain things
to asses the ability of the bit of your brain that understands humour and see if it is affected by doing other tasks simultaneously, processing information maybe
to develop new ways for impaired people to carry out normal writing tasks
to establish the possibility of developing products disabled people can operate using their mouths

the purpose of this experiment is to access the psychological status (how theyre feeling) of the individual who uses part of their body to do some simple tasks or tasks that are on the daily basis (that they don’t normally use)

the purpose of this study was to evaluate ones ability to perform actions unusual to daily life. The cartoons provided insight to intellectual ability (understand the context) and sense of humour. These insights allow the study of correlation between mood and intellect to ease performance and level of ability in the pen-in-mouth exercise. Though, I feel it may have been useful to perform the activity again after reading the cartoons to see if that ellicited a change in functionality
to see if the participant works better using a pen in thie mouth with different emotions (eg more relaxed)
to see how quickly people adopt to a situation post-stress and adopt to new ways of doing things
to test peoples modd/responses following a difficult and un-natural task
to see what demographic do everything properly and which try to find a trick around it? For example keep pen still and move paper
to see if the different tasks made it easier for you to use the pen in your mouth. More concentration if tasks better you could write with the pen
to see how successfully people can use a pen/perform activities with the use of a limb/body part which they are not accustomed to using. Also to gauge people emotional response to these activities
to see how motor skills are affected by changing of the mood of the person
the purpose of this experiment is to see how difficult/easy tasks are when not doing tasks in their usual way
to predict the effect of humour on psychomotoric control
how well people can follow instructions when they know they are being filmed - but are faced with difficult tasks
to measure the reaction time of people with something in their mouth
to see if there is any correlation between ability and personality
if the more participants struggle the less amused they feel
see how well developed our motor skills are without hands, see how may be for a person with neuro/motor problems and see how well we can follow instruction

the purpose is to find alternate ways to express something whether it be in writing, speed etc. because some people have disabilities and other ailments that make it hard for them to express normally so using alternate methods would be ideal
the purpose is to see how doing daily chores using ways that aren't normal can effect our emotions and concentration on the tasks
left blank
to see if participants are more/less amused by cartoons whilst holding pen in their mouth
to see correlations between personality and their ability to use alternative methods of completing every day tasks
the purpose of the experiment is to see how well our brains can use other parts of our body to write with and adjust to different ways of doing so
the purpose of the study was to determine whether we can hold the pen in a comfortable way in the same way as using our hand when drawing the lines on the paper
To better understand the difficulties and challenges linked to using 'unusual' body parts for trivial, everyday thing

Study how people can adapt their behaviour to a current situation. Since disabled people can adapt quite successfully with practice, this study is to measure accuracy, speed and difficuly in non-disabled people with no prior practice to the used method of writing
To study the difficulty of writing with mouth
To determine a cheap alternative way to write in order to help people with disabilities
Motor coordination - How changing physical capabilities can alter how you take in and compute information
See how we use… unnatural parts of the body
To investigate whether the sense of humor is influenced by the distraction of holding the pen with my mouth, not my hands
Exact story as cover story
Performing a mundane task in an awkawrd manner would affect co-ordinabce and speed of the task
To understand mechanisms of alternative methods of communication (i.e. writing) for those unable to use their hands
To help people with disabilities in life
To see how it is to be impaired and how difficult it can be for people
See how well people who don't write like this normally, can write, then they can compare it to those who do write like this and compare the similarities and differences
Testing our ability to control movement when amused vs. not amused where the type of movement is not normally used
To see if mood affects how hard we will try at a task
See how emotion affects how I control the pen to do a simple task
To observe ability of people (who are able to use their hands) with tasks that people who arent able to use their hands do on a daily basis and compare the two
To see how you perform in tasks that you would not normally carry out and whether getting recorded by the camera affects performance
To test how people's ability to write with unusual parts of the body is linked to their sense of humor
The cartoon part may be the effect that your expression has on how funny you find things, as holding a pen in your mouth forces you not to smile when you read the cartoon
To see how well different people can use alternative ways to carry out tasks that compensate for loss of particular features and how people react
Co-ordination of different body parts
To assess tbe ability to follow instructions of an unfamiliar task when performing an action with a body part which isnt typically used for this function, and how successful we are
I am unsure
About psychomotor. To know how disabled works and their ability to do normal activities
No answer

The effect of increasing mental stimulation requiring more thought on motor control ie. the more thought something has, the lower your ability to perform motor functions. Further, how this would impact on people with disabilities
